# Violin plots {.unnumbered} :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false} ## Graph info ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #02577A;"} **Should I use this graph?** :::
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](violin_plot_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #02577A;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.90em; color: #043b67;"} ✅ a numeric (continuous) variable ::: :::: ## Description Violin plots will display the distribution of a single numeric (continuous) variable. If you're trying to view the shape of a continuous distribution across the groups or levels of a categorical variable, check out [grouped violin plots.](https://mjfrigaard.github.io/ggp2-gallery/dist/grouped_violin_plots.html) The violin plot is essentially a mirrored density plot, in which a smoothed distribution is plotted symmetrically across the `x` or `y` axis, creating a Rorschach-like inkblot area for the distribution: ::: {.column-margin} ![source: Rorschach test, Wikipedia](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/70/Rorschach_blot_01.jpg){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ## Getting set up :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Packages ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Install packages. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by @allison_horst](../www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} The `penguins` data. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins glimpse(penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 344 Columns: 8 $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adel… $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgerse… $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3, 38.9, 39.2, 34.1, … $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6, 17.8, 19.6, 18.1, … $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181, 195, 193, 190, 186… $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650, 3625, 4675, 3475, … $ sex male, female, female, NA, female, male, female, male… $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007… ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## The grammar :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Code ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Create labels with `labs()` Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` - Place an empty string (`""`) in the `x` argument Map and empty string (`""`) to the `x` and `flipper_length_mm` to the `y` Add `geom_violin()` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_violin <- labs( title = "Adult foraging penguins", subtitle = "Distribution of flipper length", x = "", y = "Flipper length (millimeters)") ggp2_violin <- ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = '', y = flipper_length_mm)) + geom_violin() ggp2_violin + labs_violin ``` ::: ::: ### Graph ::: {style="font-size: 1.15em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](violin_plot_files/figure-html/create_graph_violin-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::::
